QUESTIONS FOR ORAL ANSWER
(Order of calling)


    Mr Speaker: Mr Barker, before I call the Questions, there is one Question addressed to you in your capacity of Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. I propose to take it in its normal place, which would be after Question No. 13. Is that acceptable to you?

    Mr E. W. Barker (Minister for Law and National Development): Yes, Sir.

Column: 255

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SINGAPORE AIRPORT
(Improvement to technical facilities)


    1. Mr Yeoh Ghim Seng asked the Deputy Prime Minister what measures are being taken to improve the technical facilities at the Singapore Airport so that it will acquire a reputation among international airlines as an equal to the safest airports in the world.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, the Member for Joo Chiat need not really worry that Singapore Airport lacks a reputation as being a safe airport. The fact that there are 20 airlines operating through Singapore is eloquent evidence that facilities at Singapore Airport are acceptable to them. And, in fact, there is a Facilitations Committee which consists of my officials as well as representatives from the airlines which meets frequently to discuss what measures we ought to introduce at the Singapore Airport that will make commercial operations viable.

Column: 256



    The I.C.A., or the International Civil Aviation organisation, of which Singapore is a member, prescribes standards regarding airport operations. They include air traffic control, radio communications, air navigational and landing heads, fire and rescue services, meteorological and other aeronautical information services. As far as Singapore is concerned, we have complied with the prescribed standards, and the Member no doubt is referring to a newspaper article published sometime ago in which criticism was directed at all airports in Asia, excepting Hongkong.

    I would like to remind Members of the House that the approach to Singapore is free of hilly obstructions; neither do we suffer the disadvantage of having fog which interferes with the vision of pilots. Because we do not have these disadvantages, we must, therefore, use our common sense and discretion in equipping Singapore Airport.

    I might mention that once upon a time Singapore had housing by-laws which were taken wholesale from the United Kingdom building by-laws when Singapore was under colonial administration. One by-law insisted that the roofs of houses in Singapore must be built at an angle of 60° so that when snow falls the snow will slide off the roof. It was only in recent years that we removed this by-law as it was patently obvious that snow does not fall in Singapore.

    The moral that I would like to draw is that it would be foolish for us to insist on, or to have imposed upon us, the facilities and standards which are required only in those airports which face the perennial problem of fog or hazardous approach due to obstruction by hills.

Column: 256

NON-CITIZENS IN CIVIL SERVICE ELIGIBLE FOR
SINGAPORE CITIZENSHIP


    2. Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi asked the Minister for Finance the number of non-citizens in the Civil Service eligible for Singapore citizenship under the proviso to paragraph (c) of

Column: 257

Article 57 (1) of the Constitution who have applied for citizenship and the number who have not.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, the present policy is that only Division I and Division II Government officers are eligible for the reduced period of residential qualification to qualify for citizenship under the proviso to Article 57 (1) (c) of the Constitution. We do not recruit non-citizens into Division III and Division IV posts.

    There are a total of 697 officers in Divisions I and II who are non-Singapore citizens. Of these, 471 officers are eligible for Singapore citizenship under this proviso. 196 are not eligible and 30 are expatriate officers. Of the 471 eligible for citizenship, 387 or 82 per cent have taken advantage of the concession and have applied for citizenship. The 84 who have not applied comprise 47 officers in Division I and 37 in Division II. The 47 Division I officers are mostly medical and dental officers. The majority of the 37 officers in Division II are teachers.

    Mr Tang See Chim (Choa Chu Kang): Sir, what does the Minister propose to do about the 47 Division I officers who do not wish to apply for Singapore citizenship?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: In my answer I said that the majority of these 47 Division I officers are medical and dental officers. They are performing technical duties and are not concerned with policy-making decisions, and I propose to do nothing about it.

    Mr Tang See Chim: Sir, should there be available Singapore citizens who can take over these posts, would the Minister consider replacing the non-citizens with local citizens?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: When we get the situation where we have more doctors than we need, I think we will consider that particular proposition.

Column: 258



    Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampong Kembangan)(In Malay): What about the 37 Division II officers, most of whom are teachers?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I will give them more time to consider the offer.

Column: 258

MR. H. F. G. LEEMBRUGGEN
(Reasons for resignation from Civil Service)


    3. Mr Tang See Chim asked the Minister for Finance whether he is aware that Mr H. F. 0. Leembruggen in a letter to the Straits Times published on 2nd September, 1967, stated that the reasons given to the House by the Minister of State, Prime Minister's Department, on 29th June, 1967, in reply to a Question on Mr Leembruggen's resignation from the Civil Service were not correct and whether he will clarify the matter.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I am aware that Mr Leembruggen in a letter to the Straits Times published on the 2nd September this year stated that the reasons given to the House by the Minister of State, Prime Minister's Department, regarding his refusal of promotion and subsequent resignation from the Civil Service were not correct. Mr Leembruggen might have other reasons known only to himself. Those given in the reply to the House were the ones determined from him at that time and were also consistent with the circumstances of his case.

Column: 258

LIBERALISATION OF INCOME TAX ASSESSMENTS AND
COLLECTION FROM FOREIGN ARTISTES


    4. Mr Yeoh Ghim Seng asked the Minister for Finance (a) what was the amount and percentage of income tax collected in 1966 from foreign artistes; (b) if he is aware that the present income-tax assessments of foreign artistes and the mode of collection are discouraging talented overseas musicians, dancers and actors from performing in Singapore; and (c) as the performances of such artistes can be a means of fostering the progress of the performing arts in

Column: 259

Singapore, if he will consider liberalising the allowances and modes of assessment and collection of income tax from foreign artistes as an incentive to talented overseas performers to come to perform in Singapore.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, this is a question in three parts, and my answers are as follows:-

    (a) Approximately $205,000 were collected in income tax from foreign artistes in 1966. This works out to 0.18 per cent of the total income tax collected during that year.

    (b) I am not aware that the present income tax assessments of foreign artistes and the mode of collection are discouraging talented overseas musicians, dancers and actors from performing in Singapore. In 1965 there were 381 foreign artistes. In 1966 the number increased to 636, i.e., there was an increase of 67 per cent; and in the first 9 months of 1967 Singapore had 666 foreign artistes.

    The system of collection is basically similar to that used by income tax authorities all over the world.

    (c) I agree that the performance of talented artistes can be a means of fostering the progress of the performing arts in Singapore. Foreign artistes whose visits are financed by public funds of another country are exempt from tax. All artistes are given reasonable allowances for expenses as laid down in the law. These allowances include expenditure on make-up, hair-dos, costumes, laundry, accommodation, travel, and so on. Where the artistes are on a circuit, stopping at other places than Singapore, only a portion of their passage expenditure attributable to their performance in Singapore is allowed.

    There is no evidence to suggest, and I am not convinced, that income tax is the crucial factor in determining the number of foreign artistes performing in Singapore. However, a Bill is being introduced to reduce the rate of income tax payable by non-residents deriving income from employment in Singapore, from 40 per cent to 15 per cent. This

Column: 260

will apply to all persons taking up employment in Singapore for short periods. Artistes will benefit by this concession.

Column: 260

CENSUS FOR SINGAPORE


    5. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Finance whether and when a census of the population of Singapore will be conducted; and whether it will be similar to the 1957 census.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: A census of the population will be carried out in 1970. I hope that it will be an improvement on the 1957 census.

Column: 260

IMPORTED NON-LUXURY GOODS
(Comparative prices)


    6. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Finance if he will make a statement on comparative prices of non-luxury goods (including food-stuffs) imported into Singapore from India, China and Japan and those imported from America, the United Kingdom and Germany.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: My difficulty is that I do not know what the hon. Member means by "non-luxury goods", and no doubt his definition, if he attempts it, will differ from mine or anybody else's. We import no less than 1,470 different items from the countries he mentioned, and they are worth $1,521.3 million last year. So I am afraid that unless the hon. Member narrows considerably the scope of his question, I would not know what is the information he is seeking.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I can give an example -for instance, footwear. The footwear we import from China as compared with the footwear we import from the United Kingdom, Germany, or America.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: No doubt, Mr Speaker, Sir, footwear imported from China will be much cheaper than footwear imported from Germany, the United Kingdom or America. But I hope that the hon. Member, as a patriotic citizen of Singapore, will only buy locally-made Singapore footwear.

Column: 261



    Mr Tang See Chim: Is the Minister aware that a certain brand of locally-made footwear can be purchased at a cheaper rate from Johore Bahru than from Singapore?

    Mr Ho See Beng rose -

    Mr Speaker: Mr Tang, I do not think that is a supplementary question. Mr Ho, did you have a further supplementary?

    Mr Ho See Beng: No.

Column: 261

ARBITRARY PRICE INCREASES BY PETROLEUM COMPANIES
(Government action)


    7. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Finance (a) whether he will look into the question of arbitrary price increases by large and monopolistic commercial firms, in particular the giant petroleum companies; (b) what steps he proposes to take to save the public from having to shoulder the burden of any possible increase in freight charges in respect of petroleum brought to Singapore for refining; and (c) whether he will consider introducing legislation imposing limits on advertising expenditure in art effort to reduce the prices of petroleum products in Singapore.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: There are no arbitrary price increases by large and monopolistic commercial firms in Singapore where market conditions are generally highly competitive. We are, in fact, one of the few remaining outposts of free enterprise in the world.

    The oil companies have decided not to increase the prices of their products. Though the oil companies at one time tried to increase the prices of their products, they finally decided not to do so. For some time they were considering how much of the increased freight could be passed on to the consumer and how much could be absorbed by them. Shell Company were in continuous touch with the Government, and they finally decided to meet the whole of their additional freight costs and retain existing prices. The other oil companies

Column: 262

decided to do the same. I think they did the right thing in taking a long-term view of the situation.

    As regards the third part of his question, the hon. Member assumes that reducing advertising expenditure would lead to lower prices. I do not think everyone would be as confident as he is about this. My own inclination is to allow free competition to settle market prices. Once you start fiddling with the market mechanism, you will find that one thing leads to another, and before you know where you are you have landed yourself in an unholy mess.

    Mr Tang See Chim: Does the Minister agree that in regard to petroleum there is no such thing as a free market in Singapore? The price is fixed by the oil companies themselves.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: There is what is called non-price competition. Prices are agreed, as the hon. Member has suggested, but there is an immense amount of competition in getting a share of the market at those agreed prices. So in this sense we can say that there is free competition in the oil market, though it is not competition in terms of price cutting but competition in terms of non-price, that is, advertising, getting more retail outlets and that sort of thing.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Can the Minister give us the figures of the expenditure on advertising in respect of the oil companies?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I am afraid I cannot.

Column: 262

OIL REFINERIES
(Capital investment and employee establishment)


    8. Mr Bernard Rodrigues asked the Minister for Finance if he will ascertain and inform the House (a) the total amount of capital invested to-date by the oil refineries which were given pioneer status and various incentive benefits; and (b) breakdown figures of (i)

Column: 263

the number of employees newly recruited, locally and from abroad, by the various oil companies for the refineries; and (ii) the number of employees transferred from the various departments of the oil companies to the refineries.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The total fixed capital investment of the oil refineries which were given pioneer status to date amounts to $124,814,575.00. To date the employment of the oil refineries given pioneer status numbers 398, and of these 56 were transferred from other departments and trained for the refineries. The local employees number 378 and foreign employees 20.

    Mr Bernard Rodrigues (Telok Blangah): Is the Minister aware that despite the pioneer status given to the Shell Group, they are preparing early retirement for some 400 employees which may ultimately lead to their retrenchment?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, I am not aware of that. The fact that a company is given pioneer status does not mean that it is not entitled to reduce its staff if it finds that it has excessive staff for the work and for the market that it has to serve.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Will the Minister support the Shell Company in the event that there is a manpower exercise which leads to the dismissal or retrenchment of 400 or so employees? And in the event that the company is willing to compensate all those affected employees, will the Minister support the Company's policy for this retrenchment, if the company can pay sufficient compensation to the employees?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I am not quite sure what the supplementary question is. I do not think I am called upon to support or oppose any action taken by a private firm in respect of its own staff. All private firms have the right under the law to increase or to reduce their staff according to what they think is in the interest of their business. One hopes, of course, that employers will not retrench staff unless there are over-riding reasons for so doing. In the case of Shell

Column: 264

Company, I have always known them to be very good employers paying good wages, and in the event that they find it regrettably necessary to reduce or retrench staff, they have always paid very handsome retrenchment terms.

    Mr Bernard Rodrigues: Sir, I thought pioneer status was given to companies to help reduce the unemployment market?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: No, Sir. Pioneer certificates are given to companies for producing pioneer products. And when they produce a new product or establish a factory, it follows that they will give more employment to people. In the case of Shell Company, it could well be that they have found that they have got an excessive number on their establishment. If this is the case, then in the interest of efficiency and higher productivity, it is quite open to them and it is only right that they reduce their staff to the number that they think they need to carry out their work efficiently.

Column: 264

FACTORIES IN JURONG INDUSTRIAL ESTATE
(Employment figures)


    9. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Finance (a) how many factories are now in operation at the Jurong Industrial Estate and how many workmen are employed by them; and (b) how many such factories have closed down or ceased operation.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: There are 94 factories in operation in Jurong employ, ing 8,800 persons. No factory in Jurong has closed down or ceased operation.

Column: 264

IMPORT OF FOREIGN GOODS
(Relaxation of quotas)


    10. Mr Lee Teck Him asked the Minister for Finance if he will consider relaxing the quotas on the import of foreign goods where the local production of similar goods is insufficient to meet the local demand, as a relief to importers who are experiencing a decline in their trade because of quotas.

Column: 265



    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, where local production is inadequate to meet local demand for a particular commodity which is subject to quota licensing, a relaxation of quota restrictions is allowed. For instance, the quota on matches was immediately liberalised in December last year from one per cent of 1964 imports to 75 per cent when it was found that there was a shortage of this commodity in the market. There were many other occasions when similar action was taken. The quota on builders' hardware was completely removed in March this year when it became clear that the local factory was going to shut down because of various difficulties. During the Middle East crisis some time this year, quota restrictions on a number of commodities, such as electrodes, cables, galvanised wire and calcium carbide, were immediately lifted to ensure that importers had sufficient stocks to meet demand.

    Moreover, where there is evidence that a local manufacturer is trying to exploit consumers by either arbitrarily increasing prices or by deliberately reducing production to create an artificial shortage of a commodity, import restrictions have also been relaxed. Undergarments are a case in point. It was discovered that the price of imported garments had been increased, but the local factory did not increase its production. Similarly the quota on wire nails was increased from 10 per cent of 1963 imports to 50 per cent early this year when the two local factories arbitrarily increased their prices. The hon. Member is, of course, aware of Government's action in granting a licence to import 10,000 tons of cement, duty free, when a temporary shortage developed in September.

    In issues such as these, the paramount consideration is the welfare of the consumer and not the earnings of importers. I have repeatedly informed our business community - and this includes importers - that where we can produce a commodity which we have previously imported, we shall do so. Importers who know the product and the local market

Column: 266

are in a good position to enter into a manufacturing venture to produce the commodity. If they fail to do so and suffer a decline in income as a consequence, they have nobody but themselves to blame for not having taken seriously Government's declared policy on industrialisation.

    Mr Lee Teck Him (Tiong Bahru)(In Mandarin): According to the Minister, of course, this is very good. But for the local factories which are not producing enough, I hope the quota system will be more liberalised in order to meet the demands of the consumers. Ours is a trading city and we should enable the traders to do their business under better conditions.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, that is precisely the point I was making.

    Mr Tang See Chim: Does the Minister agree that there is always a time lag between the increase in price and the relaxation of quota restrictions during which the consuming public will suffer and the manufacturers will benefit? Will the Minister, in such circumstances, consider introducing more stringent regulations to penalise unscrupulous local manufacturers who take advantage of the special protection given to them by the Government to exploit the consuming public?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, I think it is possible to exaggerate the extent of this problem. There has been a very substantial increase in our domestic manufactures, and the number of instances where shortages developed is very small in proportion to our production. On the whole, I would say that our manufacturers have acted with great responsibility and it is only the odd persons, either deliberately or otherwise, who have caused a shortage of supply. There must be a time lag surely. Otherwise we would have acted before there is any increase in price and we could hardly justify our action under such circumstances.

Column: 267



    Mr Ho See Beng: Will the Minister assure this House that if a time lag arises, he will do something to restrict local manufacturers from exploiting the consuming public? There has been a lot of talk that the public always has to pay double the prices of goods which we used to import in the past, but which are now being manufactured locally. And if this thing is not stopped, I think the public will have no confidence in Singapore manufactured goods.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, I am astounded that a leader of the trade union movement has expressed such sentiments. Is he not aware of the thousands of workers given employment in new industries, or does he want to see these compatriots of his thrown out of work? As for local products costing twice the imported products, I challenge the hon. Member to mention just one product and quote chapter and verse where the local product costs twice the imported product.

Column: 267

ASSISTANCE TO DECLINING WHOLESALE TRADE


    11. Mr Lee Teck Him asked the Minister for Finance whether he has any proposals to assist the wholesale trade in view of the importance of that trade to the economy of Singapore and in view of the decline in that trade, a situation which is not eased by the practice whereby some local manufacturers do not distribute their goods through wholesalers but sell direct to retailers.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, trade in Singapore, far from declining, is, in fact, on the increase. For the 12-month period ending July 1967, external trade totalled $7,783.3 million which exceeds the volume of trade in 1959, a record year. In the last 12 months, i.e., August 1966 to July 1967, imports have increased by 9.7 per cent and exports by 10.8 per cent over the similar period August 1965 to July 1966. Prospects are therefore very good that 1967 will register the highest ever volume of trade done in the history of the Republic.

Column: 268



    Reflecting the increase in trade is the amount of cargo loaded and discharged in Singapore. Thus for the 12-month period ending in July 1967, cargo discharged amounted to 17.9 million freight tons. Cargo loaded was 11.4 million freight tons, which exceeds the annual volume of cargo handled in the past eight years. There is therefore no need to give assistance to trade or in any way interfere with the free competition in our trade.

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Sir, what I asked in my question is about manufacturers selling their goods to retailers direct, which is not the correct way of doing business. Will the Minister answer to the point?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I beg your pardon, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Dr Goh, if I may paraphrase the Member's supplementary. He would like to know if you will do anything to ease the situation for wholesalers, a situation which is aggravated by local manufacturers selling direct to retailers and not through wholesalers. The Member's apparent concern is in the last three lines of his question.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I see no reason to help wholesalers because if a local manufacturer can cut out one stage in the circulation of his goods, that means the consumer gets his goods at a cheaper price. Therefore, wholesalers who suffer from this should change their occupation to other lines which are more in keeping with their usefulness to the economy.

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Sir, I do not quite understand what the Minister has said. What I asked is that manufacturers should sell their goods to the wholesalers and not direct to the retailers. I would like the Minister to pay attention to this point. The reason is that manufacturers are producing in large quantities. If the goods are not sold to the wholesalers or the agents, then the wholesalers and the agents will not have any goods to sell to the retailers

Column: 269

and consumers. If the manufacturers sell direct to the retailers, what are the wholesalers or agents going to do?

    Mr Speaker: Dr Goh, can you repeat your answer?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, if the manufacturer sells direct to the retailers and does not make use of the wholesalers, it means the services of the wholesalers are unnecessary. There is no point in making use of unnecessary economic services and paying these people. Therefore, if they are out of job, they should go and do something else.

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Sir, allow me several minutes more to ask another question.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Lee, if you have a supplementary, please ask it. I cannot allow a debate. If you are not happy with the Minister's answer, there are other devices whereby you can criticise the Minister, but you cannot do by way of a supplementary that asks no question.

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Thank you, Sir. We should look into this situation where many manufacturers are now selling their products direct to the retailers. The manufacturers ought to sell their goods to the wholesalers or agents so that they may make a living. If the manufacturers sell direct to the consumers, to me or to you, how are they going to make a living? They must sell to the wholesalers. It should be the case for manufacturers to sell to wholesalers.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, those who are in the manufacturing business are there in business. They are not charitable institutions to support families of wholesalers.

Column: 270

FIRMS AND COMPANIES AFFECTED
BY INDONESIAN CONFRONTATION
(Resumption of operations and effect on employment situation)


    12. Mr Lim Soo Peng asked the Minister for Finance how many of the firms and companies that were assisted by the Government when they were affected by Indonesian confrontation and had to lay off workers have since resumed operation; and the extent to which such resumption of operation has affected the employment situation.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The Government did not assist any firms or companies affected by confrontation. Assistance was given not to businessmen but to workers who lost their jobs as a result of confrontation. It is only possible for me to give the total number of firms and companies directly affected by confrontation and brought within the scope of the Economic Defence Scheme established in 1963. (INCORPORATION) BILL

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr S. Ramaswamy): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    This Bill is designed to incorporate the Rubber Association of Singapore (hereinafter called "the Corporation") as a corporate body.

    Since its inception in 1963, the Rubber Association of Singapore has been responsible for regulating transactions in the Singapore rubber market. Its responsibilities were inherited from its original sponsors, the Rubber Trade Association of Singapore and the Singapore Chamber of Commerce Rubber Association. The Association not only deals in the day-to-day operation of the clearing house, regulation of trading, shipping and fixing of prices, but also in the fields of contracts, arbitration, packing standards and disciplining of the market.

    The Association's income depends entirely on members' subscriptions, tender fees and commissions on auction sales. In recent years, the Association's income from these sources has declined. To enable the Association to function effectively and competitively and to maintain and approve the high standards of conduct of the Singapore rubber market, it is clearly necessary that the Association should have adequate finances. With this in mind, the Association approached Government with a proposal that it should be authorised to levy a cess on rubber exportation from Singapore and to use the proceeds of the cess to cover its expenditure. Since there were, however, legal objections to empowering the Association, as incorporated under the Societies Ordinance, to collect a cess,

Column: 293

it was considered that the most appropriate means of overcoming these objections was to constitute a Corporation to replace the Association. The assets and property of the Association would then vest in the Corporation. This is offered under clauses 3 and 4 of the Bill.

    The principal objects of the Corporation are to promote sales and exports of rubber from Singapore, to collect a cess on rubber exports for this purpose, and make rules and regulations governing the marketing of rubber (clauses 4 and 14). The management of the statutory body is vested in a Management Committee, which consists of 15 members, seven of whom are nominated by the Rubber Trade Association of Singapore and seven of whom are nominated by the Singapore Chamber of Commerce Rubber Association. The remaining member is a public officer. It is proposed that this public officer will be the Director of Trade of the Ministry of Finance. This officer will not, however, be concerned with the day-to-day operations of the Rubber Association. The Chairman and Deputy Chairman will be appointed by the Minister from the 14 members of the Committee representing the two component associations mentioned above (clause 10).

The Committee will, subject to the directions of the Minister, control the Singapore Rubber Fund which is established under clause 13 of the Bill. All moneys received by the Committee, including the proceeds of any cess collected under clause 14, will be paid into this Fund and the Fund will be used to pay the expenses of the administration of the Committee and for carrying out the purposes of this legislation generally.
